And that after his return there he was exiled,  out of jealousy and suspicion,  by his fellow - citizens,  Augustus having refused to intervene actively.  Strabo's use of the word àgxri for his position at the time is not regarded as decisive in favour of his having established himself as sole ruler.  This view is put forward with no small skill and ingenuity,  but the author cannot find a convincing explanation of Strabo's term rjyeixévy as applied to Eurykles,  and has also to find an alternative interpretation of the coins with the legend eni EvQvxXéovÇy of which an immense number were struck,  as well as of those of the time of Claudius inscribed enl Adxcovoç,  The answer given is that both series were coined under Eurykles,  and Laco after him,  as High - priests of the Emperor ; but this would involve the consequence,  ignored by the author,  that they were eponymous High - priests!  This is a matter above all for the verdict of the numismatists,  but in any case the absence of the word àgxtegécoç would seem strange,  and we have no direct evidence ( apart from a single small altar inscribed Eeßaaribi Kabaqiy IG,  V.  i,  373 ) for the Imperial cult at Sparta during the life - time of Augustus.  The suggestion ( p.  195 ff.  ) that it may have been established early in his reign ( on the analogy of the cults at Nicomedia and Pergamon ) is mere guess - work. 
The career of his son Laco is carefully studied,  with the conclusion that he was exiled from Sparta by order of Tiberius c.  A.  D.  31,  when over fifty years of age ; and became domiciled,  and held office,  at Corinth,  as did his son Spartiaticus ; and therefore cannot be the Laco whose name appears on Claudian coins at Sparta.  To account for this second Laco an elaborate theory of adoption is put forward,  which is not easy to accept. 
The fact that the hereditary priesthood of the Emperors passed out of the direct ( or adoptive ) descendants of Eurykles on the death of Eurykles Herklanos in the reign of Hadrian,  and that his successor C.  Pomponius Alkastos was the last holder of the life - priesthood is rightly emphasised,  but is followed by some rather speculative suggestions as to the stances in which this change was made ( p.  202f.  ). 
4. 
Part II »The Earlier Sparta« opens with an account of the early Social Organisation in Sparta and Crete ( ch.  VI ) in which the resemblances in constitutional structure between Sparta and the Cretan cities are shown to be less close than Aristotle claimed.  On the other hand the social parallels,  which are fully discussed,  are seen to be more numerous and more cant than was previously realised.  This is a valuable and convincing tribution to the subject,  and the details given confirm the claim that »both in Sparta and Crete the aristocratic families sought to maintain their power
